[202] Review An Insight on Molybdenum Phosphide and its Hybrids as Catalyst for Electrochemical Water splitting: A Mini-Review Rafiq Khosa Erum Pervaiz ⁎ Uzair Abdullah Maryum Ali Umair Sohail Abdul Shakoor Heterogeneous Catalysis Lab, Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical and Materials Engineering (SCME), National University of Sciences & Technology (NUST), Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan Heterogeneous Catalysis Lab Department of Chemical Engineering School of Chemical and Materials Engineering (SCME) National University of Sciences & Technology (NUST) Islamabad 44000 Pakistan Heterogeneous Catalysis Lab, Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical and Materials Engineering (SCME), National University of Sciences & Technology (NUST), Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan ⁎ Corresponding Author In recent years, a significant interest in developing green and renewable alternate energy reserves has been observed to address the energy and environmental crisis associated with utilizing conventional fossil fuels. In this respect, Hydrogen (H2) is an effective energy carrier and has been recognized as a promising candidate for the future energy supply. Water splitting is a promising technology for producing H2. Implementation of inexpensive water splitting systems and electrolyzers could lead to market-compatible H2 fuel. Robust, efficient, and abundant catalysts are needed for the process to work favorably. Molybdenum Phosphide (MoP) has recently been identified as a promising family of earth-abundant electrocatalysts for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER). It boosts diverse compositions and structures, favorable electronic characteristics, and high electrical conductivity resulting in low overpotentials at operationally relevant current densities while exhibiting stability under strongly acidic conditions. In this review, we highlight the progress that has been made in this field and provides insights into the synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical behavior of MoP as HER electrocatalyst. Introduction Climate change and the increasing global energy crisis are two major challenges for an advanced society. It is mandatory to develop viable clean energy carriers and energy conversion technologies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and fossil fuel dependence. Hydrogen (H2), like green energy and carbon-free carrier, keeps a more energy capacity, which is sponsored as the up-and-coming nominee for the potential energy resource [1,2]. Now, huge H2 production largely depends on the steam reforming reaction of fossil sources, which provokes the carbon footstep and reduction of fossil fuels [3–5]. Water electrolysis is generally recognized as a more sustainable and viable technique of H2 production than the stream reforming reaction due to its advantages of using water as a reactant, the absence of greenhouse gas emissions, and exceptional H2 generation efficiency [6–8]. Electrochemical water splitting is a highly efficient method of producing H2. It is regarded as a storage technology and a sustainable energy conversion method that has the potential to diminish and alleviate the mounting concerns of fossil fuel exhaustion and global pollution [9–11]. For effective H2 generation, a highly active HER electrocatalyst is required. For HER, Pt-group metals have been chosen as the most efficient electrocatalysts due to their superior hydrogen absorption. However, their earth scarcity and high costs have proven to be significant barriers to commercialization [12,13]. Alternative electrocatalysts development has been necessary to lower manufacturing costs and increase HER performance. Transition metals with unique characteristics and a high earth abundance have received considerable attention in developing active electrocatalysts for HER. As a result, high-performance nonnoble metal electrocatalysts, such as carbides, nitrides, metal alloys, chalcogenides, borides, and non-metal electrocatalysts, are required [14–16]. The transition metal Molybdenum Phosphide (MoP) has greatly benefited due to its diverse compositions and structures, favorable electronic characteristics, and high electrical conductivity [17–19]. As a result, much effort has been expended on developing high-performance and cost-effective electrocatalysts, particularly Mo-based catalysts [20–22]. MoP is an active catalyst in catalyzing the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction [23,24]. Because of its inherent catalytic activity, high thermal stability, and low cost, MoP a stable hexagonal crystal structure in which Mo3+ is bonded to six equivalent P3− atoms to form face-sharing MoP6 pentagonal pyramids, has been studied extensively as a potential HER electrocatalyst [25–27]. Despite extensive attempts to optimize the catalyzing activity of MoP-based electrocatalysts, much space for enhancement in HER activity by atomic engineering and morphological modification remains. In general, with great HER activity, an ideal HER electrocatalyst should exhibit the resulting features: (i) it should depict a high density of catalytically active sites; (ii) it should enable mass transport and electron transfer; and (iii) it should optimize intermediate adsorption/desorption strengths. To achieve these goals, interface engineering and porosity engineering have been repeatedly proposed to alter the morphology and structure of MoP-based electrocatalysts to improve their HER catalytic performance [28–30]. Zhicai et al. investigated a dense network of MoP nanoparticles (MoP-CA2) with numerous nanopores, high conductivity, and a large specific surface area that has the potential to operate as an extremely active nonnoble metal catalyst for electrochemical H2 production from an acidic water medium. In the Faradaic regime, the network operates at about 100% efficiency and requires 200 and 125 mV overpotentials to manage current densities of 100 and 10 mA/cm2, respectively [31]. Shen and coworkers synthesized porous MoP nanoflakes by phosphorizing hydrothermally formed MoO2 nanoflakes on Ni foam (NF). This hierarchical MoP/NF electrocatalyst displayed remarkable catalytic performance for electrocatalysis of overall water splitting (OWS) at a cell voltage of around a current density of 10 mA/cm2 and 1.62 V. Additionally; it demonstrated exceptional stability over sustained electrolysis of bulk alkaline water [27]. Compared to carbon, phosphorus has relevant properties such as lower electronegativity and bigger atomic size, making it an attractive choice for replacing O2 in the interface between the MoO2 and MoP domains [32]. After thermal phosphidation and subsequent acid treatment of an iron-molybdenum oxide (Fe2Mo2O9–12) NW precursor on carbon cloth (CC), Y. Teng and colleagues developed MoP nanowires that retained their original form. At a high current density of 100 mA/cm2, the MoP NW/CC electrode exhibits a low overpotential of 173 mV and a low onset potential of 72 mV, a low Tafel slope of 53 mV/dec, and increased durability in an acid medium [33]. Dong-Yeop Lee demonstrated a novel method for producing MoP nanoparticles as an efficient HER electrocatalyst throughout a wide pH range by employing porous CC [34]. Reduced graphene oxide (RGO) has gained considerable research interest as a promising platform for enhanced electrocatalysts in various electrochemical energy conversion activities. Its versatile service is mainly recognized for its unique chemical and physical properties, like excellent electronic structure, high specific surface area, and functionalization and structural modification [35,36]. A simple hydrothermal technique produces N-doped molybdenum oxide, which is then annealed in an N2 atmosphere and phosphorated to generate a sphere-shaped N-doped oxygenated MoP. The newly found N-doped phosphide structure improves HER catalytic performance by obtaining a low overpotential of about 87 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2, which is better than the 138 mV overpotential of annealed N-doped molybdenum oxide in alkaline medium. Because of its large exposed surface, broad electrode/electrolyte interface, and reactant-specific binding energies, N-MoP is a particularly potent electrocatalyst for HER catalysis [37]. The goal of this review article is to give a systematic and complete overview of MoP and its hybrids as electrochemical water splitting catalysts. Fundamental of Water Splitting Water splitting into H2 and O2 has generated huge research attention as a viable method of obtaining sustainable and renewable energy [38,39]. In a normal device for electrochemical water splitting, HER and OER are identical at cathode and anode, respectively. The Fig. 1 depicts the basic components of an OWS system. Depending on the electrolyte, which can be neutral (including seawater), alkaline or acidic, the OWS reaction and two half-reactions can be stated as follows (Eqs. (1), (2), (3), (4) and (5)) [40,41]. In acidic media (1) OER ( Oxidation , Anode ) : H 2 O + 2 e − → 0 . 5 O 2 ( ↑ ) + 2 H + W E 0 anode = 1 . 23 V (2) HER ( Cathode , Reduction ) : 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 ( ↑ ) E 0 cathode = 0 . 00 V In neutral or alkaline media (3) OER ( Oxidation , Anode ) : 2 O H − + 2 e − → 0 . 5 O 2 ( ↑ ) + 2 H 2 O E 0 anode = 1.23 V (4) HER ( Cathode , Reduction ) : 2 H 2 O + 2 e − → H 2 ( ↑ ) + 2 O H − E 0 cathode = 0.00 V (5) Total reaction : 2 H 2 O → O 2 ( ↑ ) + 2 H 2 ( ↑ ) The thermodynamics voltage value of electrocatalytic water splitting vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at 1atm and 25°C is 1.23 V, and this value is independent of the reaction conditions. The additional voltage must be delivered to the cell in the study. The overall cell voltage (Voc) can be expressed as below (Eq. 6) (6) V o c = 1.23 V + η a + ∥ η c ∥ + i R Where ηc and ηa represent the cathodic and anodic overpotentials (the gap between the equilibrium and applied electrode potential, respectively), and iR represents the ohmic drop. As a result, a major effort must be made to design particularly active catalysts that are cost-effective for the OER and HER in an electrolyze device to achieve H2 economy by electrochemical water electrolysis [43]. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are attractive candidates as electrocatalysts for HER due to their high stability and electrocatalytic activity [44]. MoP is an outstanding electrocatalyst for HER among the TMPs due to its similar electrical structure to that of Pt-group metals, as well as its stability and strong electrocatalytic activity across a broad pH range [45]. Enjun Jiang used KOH electrolyte and Mo-chelated resin as intermediates to describe the simple phosphating-carbonization-activation of a bifunctional electrocatalyst composed of coupled Mo2C-MoP-quantum dots organized on a 3D highly porous nanosheets P, N-doped carbon sheet system. Both Mo2C-MoP/NPC electrocatalytic performed well in the HER and OER. As a result, an electrolyze was built with Mo2C-MoP/NPC as both the negative and positive active materials to test its OWS capability. Mo2C-MoP/NPC electrocatalyst required only 1.7 V to achieve a current density of 100 mA/cm2. Still, the Pt/C@RuO2/C electrocatalyst needed 1.8 V, and the potential differences grew significantly when the potentials grew during OWS. It is important to note that Mo2C-MoP/NPC electrocatalyst achieved a current density of 10 mA/cm2 at only 1.55 V, which is comparable to the results reported for Fe0.9 Co0.05 S1.5 electrocatalyst [46], O-doped CuO/Co2P NWs [47], and D-Ni-MOF (Metal-Organic Framework) [48], Mo2C-MoP/NPC maintained a current density of 95% of CA testing at 1.6 V after 168h, whereas RuO2/C@ Pt/C kept just 71% of its initial current density after 48h. Mo2C-MoP/NPC electrocatalyst demonstrated comparable, if not greater, stability and electrocatalytic activity to currently described state-of-the-art catalysts. Mo2C-MoP/NPC || Mo2C-MoP/NPC for OWS was further approximated in Fig. 2 , yielding a volume ratio and a value near 100% of produced O2 to H2 of 1:2. A 1.5 V AA battery supplied the HER and OER. The volume ratio of produced O2 to H2 was near 1:2, supported by the Faradic Efficiency (FE) findings that Mo2C-MoP/NPC demonstrates exceptional electrocatalytic capabilities because of the existence of extremely distributed Mo2C and MoP quantum dots generated using the chelation chemistry technique described here and the abundance of largely catalytic active sites on the skin-like Mo2C and MoP quantum dots. Additionally, it looked like the combination of Mo2C and MoP improved the electrical structure of the individual species, resulting in functional, active interfaces [49]. Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) HER is a critical reaction for selecting electrochemical processes, which offers a vital link between energy conversion applications and renewable energy resources, i.e., reversible hydrogen fuel cells [50]. This HER needs high-performance electrocatalysts to speed up the decomposition of H2O. A cathodic HER in aqueous acidic media takes place in the 2-electron-reaction model by an electrochemical “desorption step” and a “discharge step” [51]. The 1st step of the reaction is known as the Volmer reaction. An intermediate state of the H is produced by transferring an electron to one proton at the catalyst's surface. HER takes place at the cathode [52,53]. The typical mechanism for HER in acidic media e − + H + + * → H * (The Volmer reaction, electrochemical adsorption, ≈120 mV/dec) Then, two possible ways for the HER will go behind. First is Heyrovsky's reaction [54]. H * + H + + e − → H 2 (the Heyrovsky reaction, electrochemical desorption, ≈40 mV/dec) The second is the Tafel recombination reaction [55]. H * + H * → H 2 + 2 * (the Tafel reaction, ≈30 mV/dec, chemical desorption) In alkaline or neutral media H 2 O + e − + * → O H − + H * (the Volmer reaction, ≈120 mV/dec, electrochemical adsorption) H 2 O + H * + e − → H 2 + O H − (the Heyrovsky reaction, ≈40 mV/dec, electrochemical desorption) H * + H * → H 2 + 2 * (the Tafel reaction, ≈30 mV/dec, chemical desorption) The * denotes the electrocatalyst's active site. Then adsorbed H atom on the surface of the electrocatalyst in the first Volmer step, forming the adsorbed hydrogen intermediate H*. Then, depending on the H atom's adsorption energy on the electrocatalyst surface, H* interacts with H+ or H2O (the Heyrovsky reaction) or with another recently formed H* (the Tafel reaction) in alkaline or acidic conditions to liberate one H2 molecule [56]. In HER, the Volmer reaction is the fast reaction, and the other two reactions are the rate-limiting step. The Tafel slope determines a dominant mechanism. The critical parameter for the Tafel plot is to gain a low Tafel slope at a significant current density value. Tafel slope tells the overpotential of an electrochemical reaction. As much as lower the overpotential, there is an efficient HER electrocatalyst [57,58]. In an acidic solution, the Volmer step relates to the electrochemical reduction of a proton to an adsorbed H. It is determined not only by the adsorption energy but also by the desorption of hydroxide ions (OH−) and the dissociation of water in neutral and alkaline solutions. Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER) OER is also another half-reaction for the overall reaction of water splitting. The following reactions are involved in the OER mechanism in acidic media. H 2 O + * → * OH + e − + H + * OH → * O + e − + H + * O + H 2 O → * OOH + e − + H + * OOH → O 2 + e − + H + + * The typical mechanism in neutral or alkaline media is below. * + O H − → * OH + e − * OH + O H − → * O + H 2 O + e − * O + O H − → * OOH + e − * OOH + O H − → O 2 + H 2 O + e − + * The * represents the active sites on the surface of the electrocatalyst. The combination of the two newly formed intermediates, *O, to directly produce O2 gas is very difficult due to the large thermodynamic barrier [59]. OER is more complex than HER due to two H2O molecules and four-electron oxidation processes to produce one O2 molecule. OER takes place at the anode [60,61]. Still, the research publications are limited to transition metal nitrides as a catalyst for OER. OER needs the catalyst to be safe from the oxidation of O2 and in aqueous media. Mostly transition metal nitrides are unstable throughout OER, especially in aqueous media. For the OER process, voltage is required higher than 1.23 V [62,63]. Factors Affecting the Electrochemical Water Splitting Process This section introduces the basic requirements for electrocatalysts. These are the Tafel slope, overpotential (η), current density (j), and turnover frequency (TOF). TOF values are employed as performance indicators for electrocatalysts. Electrochemical activity can be determined using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) or cyclic voltammetry (CV), or overpotential is a critical criterion for the activity of HER and OER electrocatalysts [64]. Theoretically, HER and OER have onset potentials of 1.23 V for OER and 0 V for HER, respectively. Both processes, in practice, require a different potential to lower the kinetic barriers, and this additional potential is referred to as overpotential. At a given current density, the overpotential value deflects the catalytic activity. The lower the catalytic activity, the greater the electrocatalytic performance of a catalyst. Tafel slope, a critical characteristic obtained from LSV, depicts the rising current rate as potential increases. Additionally, it is a kinetic parameter. A lower value of the Tafel slope indicates that the electrocatalyst's electron transfer kinetics are faster. For the linear regions of Tafel plots, the Tafel equation is as respects: η = a + b l o g ( j / j o ) Where η is the overpotential, b represents a Tafel slope, jo represents the exchange current density, and j represents the current density. Another critical factor for determining the electrocatalytic activity of electrocatalysts is the current exchange density (jo), which is a crucial kinetic element in determining the electrochemical reaction rate at equilibrium. It indicates the rate at which an electrochemical reaction can occur when an electrocatalyst is used [65]. The linear area of the Tafel plot, which co-relates to the intersection at the overpotential = 0, can be used to derive the value of the current exchange density. Using MoP and Ni2P on glassy carbon electrodes, Xiaobo et al. studied polarization curves and discovered that the HER had a low onset potential of around 100 mV and 170 mV, respectively. Furthermore, the overpotentials required to achieve 10 mA/cm2 current density for the MoP and Ni2P catalysts were overpotential 246 mV and overpotential 346 mV, respectively, demonstrating that the outstanding catalytic activity for HER is comparable to other non-Pt electrocatalysts for HER in acidic aqueous solutions without conductive supports. It must be highlighted that the MoP catalyst outperforms the Ni2P and C-MoS2 catalysts in terms of catalytic activity. In Fig. 3 , the Tafel plots of the Pt/C and phosphides catalysts are shown, which are observed in the Tafel equation providing Tafel slopes of 60, 30, and 70 mV/dec for the MoP, Pt, Ni2P catalysts, respectively. The Tafel slope is a significant measure of HER effectiveness since it is considered an inherent catalyst feature. By increasing voltage, a small Tafel slope suggests a faster rise in HER rate. Therefore, the MoP catalyst has a higher activity than the Ni2P catalyst, which has a lower Tafel slope. While the standard Pt/C catalyst has a significantly lower Tafel slope than MoP, the efficiency of MoP catalyst may be dramatically increased by adding highly conductive support of porous C with a large surface area, hence reducing particle size. For a simple comparison, the Tables 1 and 2 describes the exchange current density and Tafel slope of numerous non-Pt HER electrocatalysts. Compared to its low mass loading, MoP catalyst exhibits a low Tafel slope and a considerable exchange current density. In this context, Ni2P and CoP nanoparticles had much smaller Tafel slopes than Ni2P and MoP microparticles, implying that nanostructure efforts can dramatically increase final HER activity. An active site's TOF may be defined as the number of desired product molecules per unit of time. The equation for TOF is given below [86], T O F = j A / 4 n F Where A is the surface area of the working electrode, n denotes the number of active sites, and F denotes the Faraday constant. Obtaining the accurate value of the TOF is difficult since it requires determining the correct number of active sites and ensuring that all catalyst sites are catalytically active. As a result, the TOF is an insufficient criterion for catalytic activity [87,88]. Even though MoP has been the subject of recent research, a thorough understanding of the active centers present in MoP as well as the parameters that may influence his activities for electrochemical OWS is important for applications in electrochemical water splitting. OWS activity is influenced by the loading amount of catalyst, the geometric structure, the intrinsic element characteristic, and the coordination environment. It is common knowledge that each element possesses unique chemical characteristics. When the atomic structures of a single metal atom vary, they can exhibit distinct properties [89,90]. The arrangement of active sites in an electrocatalyst is determined by its geometric structure. A structure would be catalytically efficient if all active sites were visible and accessible [91]. In addition to their strong catalytic activity, electrocatalysts' long-term stability is a significant component in their practical uses. Catalytic activity inherent to the electrocatalyst and the availability of active sites is the primary determinants of its activity. By creating structures with a high surface area, generating nanostructures, and altering the shape, available catalytic sites can be increased [92]. The most effective strategies for maximizing HER and OER activity involve modifying the bulk and/or surface properties by combining the selection of cations and anions, optimizing the morphology by employing advanced synthesis techniques, and enhancing the charge transfer process by modifying the surface electronic structure functionally (formation of composite or hybrid catalysts) [93,94]. Catalyst's capacity to transfer charge is crucial for achieving effective electrocatalytic activity, and this can be achieved by linking composite material, such as RGO, etc., to improve the conductivity, or charge transferability, of MOF-based electrocatalysts [95,96]. There is a competition between the chemical adsorption and desorption of H atoms on HER. An effective HER catalyst and adsorbed H must contain a sufficiently strong bond to facilitate the proton-electron transfer process while also ensuring weak, facile bond breakdown and the release of generated H2 gas [2]. Selectivity is one of the most desirable factors of an electrocatalyst, together with activity and stability, which make up the necessary trio of characteristics for an electrocatalyst with selectivity [97]. Since selectivity is one of the most important characteristics of an electrocatalyst, it is crucial to reveal the selectivity of catalysts screened for OER and HER electrocatalysis by their FE in addition to the other activity parameters previously mentioned [98]. In addition, one can add other activity parameters beyond the discussed activity parameters if they are valid and acceptable. Any activity parameter that will be proposed for an electrocatalyst must deal with any of the one or more following necessary criteria: selectivity, activity, and stability [99]. As an emerging catalytic material, MoP provides fresh insights into the mechanics of electrochemical processes. Due to their significance in the electrochemical splitting of water, the development of MoP is a major focus of research studies. Characteristic Properties of MoP and its Hybrids The use of transition-metal-based materials as non-noble-metal HER electrocatalysts has been widely investigated [100–103], including sulfides [104–107], carbides, nitrides [68,108-110], and phosphides [111]. Among these catalysts, TMPs have gained extensive attention due to their high conductivity and inherent activity comparable to noble metals, which can be ascribed to the electronegative phosphorus drawing electrons from metal ion desorption of hydrogen. Across the latest years, TMPs have demonstrated improved HER performance, with stability and high activity and in a wide pH range. MoP is a renowned HDS catalyst [24]. Since both HER and HDS need a reversible combination of H2 and catalyst, MoP may exhibit superior HER catalytic activity. Xiao et al. initially described MoP as an excellent HER catalyst in alkaline and acid electrolytes in 2014 [112]. This article compared and investigated the characteristics of Mo, Mo3P, and MoP catalysts. The results indicated that catalysts with a higher P content in MoP exhibited greater catalytic activity than those with a lesser quantity of P or an absence of P in Mo3P and Mo, respectively. Although MoP exhibited strong HER catalytic activity in bulk, it may be enhanced further by showing more active sites via nanostructures. Using (NH4)2HPO4 as the P source, Xing et al. effectively synthesized a densely linked MoP nanoparticle network with several exposed active sites [31]. N-doped carbon nanotube-graphene(NCNT-NGR) supported nanostructured MoP exhibits extraordinary HER activity in acidic solutions due to the synergy of highly active MoP nanoparticles and highly conductive NCNT-NGR substrate with a wide surface area (Fig. 4 ) [113]. Notably, high activity and the unique network structure of MoP enable it to function very well in acidic solutions, with low overpotentials of 200 and 125 mV at 100 and 10 mA/cm2, respectively. Additionally, preparing MoP/carbon composites is a viable technique for increasing the specific surface area of catalysts and exposing additional active sites. Yang et al. developed a range of Mo-based materials/porous nanostructured carbon composites (i.e., MoO2@PC, Mo2C@PC, MoP@PC, and MoN@PC) utilizing UIO-66 as the carbon precursor and various treatment methods [114]. MoP@PC had the strongest catalytic activity against HER in acidic electrolytes compared to these composites and bulk MoP. Particularly, the same morphologies of these composites revealed that MoP possessed the greatest intrinsic catalytic activity, and MoP@PC outperformed the bulk, suggesting that it included more exposed catalyst active sites. Apart from porous carbon formed from MOF, composites based on carbon compounds may also increase their dispersion and performance. Heterointerface engineering significantly influences managing the interfacial and surface characteristics of a catalyst. However, regulating the quality and amount of heterointerfaces at the 2D adjacent nanoscale remains a critical but demanding issue. As density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrate that multinary synergistic effects and their heterointerfaces can optimize the hydrogen desorption/adsorption energy (GH*) and enhance the reaction kinetics. Additionally, the ultrathin nanosheet's distinctive structure maximizes the accessibility of inner atoms and heterointerfaces to catalytic reaction sites, hence, co-assisting intrinsic catalytic activity. As a promising result, the optimized Co–Mo–P NSs demonstrate the excellent performance of HER, with a TOF of 5.5 and 3.0 times that of bare MoP and CoP, respectively. Additionally, it has excellent OER activity (η10 = 261.9 mV) and extensive, complete water decomposition [115]. Zhang et al. demonstrated the production of diverse Mo-based nanowire arrays (NWAs) on carbon fiber paper (CFP) via universal topotactic conversions. Additionally, the findings established that MoP.NWAs/CFP had the greatest electrocatalytic activity in universal pH media, requiring only modest overpotentials of 52, 56, and 84 mV in 1mol/L KOH, 0.5mol/L H2SO4, and 1mol/L PBS, respectively, to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 [116]. For MoP, raising the P concentration can significantly improve the electrocatalytic activity. MoP had the greatest intrinsic catalytic activity among many Mo-based compounds with similar shapes. However, synthesizing MoP remains a significant issue, requiring the development of novel P sources and processing methods. Transition-metal interstitial compounds (TMICs) are similar to Pt in their potential as catalytic materials (Pt) [117,118]. TMICs can activate and trap protons, making them active against HER [25,119]. Mo, a naturally occurring element, may react with P and nitrogen (N) to generate Mo-based TMICs [18,120,121]. Structure engineering is critical for constructing the active interface and increasing the number of active catalytic sites, resulting in increased HER activity [122–126]. Typically, for efficient catalysis, small-sized W and Mo-based particles have been developed in advance designed [110]. 2D materials are interesting catalysts in this area due to good exposure to a more accessible surface and their distinctive structure [127–131]. For instance, the 2D molybdenum nitrite strongly acts against HER with a η 10=129 mV [132]. Additionally, creating pores can improve mass transfer, enhancing performance enhancement [133–135]. An earlier study has shown that the small-sized Mo2N-Mo2C heterojunction anchored on holey RGO has effective HER performance [136]. Mu et al. created holey nitride/carbide heterostructure sheets for water splitting at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 and a cell voltage of 1.8 V [137]. A densely linked network of MoP particles (50 nm) proved efficient against HER (η 10=125 mV) [31]. The particles constituting the sheet and the sheet itself are relatively large, limiting its effectiveness against HER. As a result, developing 2D porous Mo-based TMIC heterojunction nanosheets composed of tiny particles is critical for efficient catalysis [138]. MoP and its Hybrids’ Applications MoP and its hybrids are mainly used in electrocatalytic water splitting. The electrocatalytic water splitting system comprises an external circuit, electrodes, and an aqueous electrolyte [181,182]. Comparing HER and OER, OER during the OWS phase is rather sluggish kinetically and needs a large potential. Additionally, OER is extremely pH-dependent, operating differently in acidic and alkaline environments. Two water molecules are oxidized at a potential of 0.404 V to generate O2 and H2 [1,183]. Critical Aspects and Future Recommendations Despite rapid advancements in using MoP-based materials as HER catalysts, few crucial and problematic challenges remain. MoP's electrical conductivity through electrochemical H2 production is a critical factor to consider. Because P atoms have high electronegativity, they significantly inhibit the delocalization of electrons of metal atoms, resulting in decreased conductivity. As the P concentration rises, the TMPs’ conductivity steadily declines, resulting in a semi-conductive or insulating property. Thus, the P content of MoP must be carefully studied and adjusted to improve HER activity and conductivity. Thorough knowledge of the catalytic activity of TMPs-based catalysts throughout the HER process is critical for developing improved electrocatalysts. It is critical to examine how catalysts evolve structurally and how reactants, intermediates, and products are converted. Ex-situ approaches could fail to examine the rebuilt surface and offer actual evidence about the intermediate's development due to the fleeting states and unavoidable air oxidation of catalysts and unstable intermediate species. As a result, in-situ characterization methods such as in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy and in-situ Raman are commonly employed while operating a basic system of electrochemical processes. Such in situ research explains active natural centers and reaction mechanisms and helps to develop improved electrocatalysts. DFT theoretical simulations have become a progressively viable method for predicting performance and designing catalysts. In the case of TMP-based catalysts as HER-active, DFT simulations can reveal the modified interaction and electronic structure of reactive species with the structure surface and the development of intermediates. Additionally, theoretical computations may forecast the best crystal shapes and chemical constitutions. However, numerous unanswered questions remain. For example, realistic models which closely resemble real-world reaction systems are critical for DFT theoretical computations. It is critical to comprehend the MoP-driven HER process to simulate electrocatalysts and reaction routes accurately. Additional work in this sector is required to guide the optimization and design of MoP-based electrocatalysts properly. When considering large-scale applications of MoP-based HER electrocatalysts, three major factors must be considered: catalytic activity, durability, and commercial availability. While MoP-based materials have been described as potential electrocatalysts for HER, their activity must be increased further compared to the Pt/C state-of-the-art catalyst. Durability is also a critical yet difficult problem for electrocatalysts based on MoP. Hydrogen adsorption energy, conductivity, nanostructure, and super oleophobic surface must be developed logically and regulated precisely. These key features interact with one another and independently fulfill distinct tasks, optimizing the performance of MoP-based catalysts. Additionally, Fe and Ni-based phosphides are regarded as potential long-term HER electrocatalysts due to their abundance on Earth. Apart from the availability of materials, practical applications require cost-effective and energy-efficient synthesis techniques. Conclusion Due to its greater HER catalytic activity and stability across a wide pH range, Mo-based materials are the most desirable candidates for replacing the costly but common Pt-based catalysts. Due to its low overpotential, porosity, stability, inexpensive and abundant nature, compatibility, and permeability, MoP is exceptional and ideal for electrocatalytic applications and processes. This article presents an overview of MoP and its hybrids for electrocatalytic and practical applications, emphasizing the fundamentals, methodology, design, and production of H2 as a renewable energy source. In addition, preparation procedures, strategies for enhancing catalytic activity, and the relationship between composition/structure and electrocatalytic performance were highlighted. Presently, considerable research efforts have enabled all Mo-based electrocatalysts to exhibit good HER performance in acidic electrolytes. An ideal catalyst should possess sufficient hydrogen adsorption energy, enough active sites, and suitable electrical conductivity. For optimizing the effectiveness of MoP, emphasis should be placed on examining research perspectives such as (1) To improve the nano structuring of the developed catalysts to increase the active catalytic surface area, enhancing the synergistic effects. By having a complete understanding of the basic processes and mechanisms, it may be possible to boost the process's efficiency greatly. Integrating experimental design with theoretical analysis, (2) a greater understanding of the kinetics and mechanism of molecular-scale processes has been achieved. Even while tremendous progress has been made, there is still a long way to go before these Mo-based materials can be utilized widely for H2 production. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, a significant interest in developing green and renewable alternate energy reserves has been observed to address the energy and environmental crisis associated with utilizing conventional fossil fuels. In this respect, Hydrogen (H2) is an effective energy carrier and has been recognized as a promising candidate for the future energy supply. Water splitting is a promising technology for producing H2. Implementation of inexpensive water splitting systems and electrolyzers could lead to market-compatible H2 fuel. Robust, efficient, and abundant catalysts are needed for the process to work favorably. Molybdenum Phosphide (MoP) has recently been identified as a promising family of earth-abundant electrocatalysts for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER). It boosts diverse compositions and structures, favorable electronic characteristics, and high electrical conductivity resulting in low overpotentials at operationally relevant current densities while exhibiting stability under strongly acidic conditions. In this review, we highlight the progress that has been made in this field and provides insights into the synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical behavior of MoP as HER electrocatalyst.
coredata.dc:title: An Insight on Molybdenum Phosphide and its Hybrids as Catalyst for Electrochemical Water splitting: A Mini-Review
